subject: RE: Re: [junit] DBC
msgSnippet: ... The way I see this is that there is a difference between a published (and public) API, and a system API. Whereas the system API is one that is subject to
messageBody:
> From a component user view point I'd still like to see a
> concise description of the prerequisites without having to
> dig into the component code or even the unit testing code...
> ... though I realise I'm in danger of reopening the javadoc v
> unit test discussion :-)

The way I see this is that there is a difference between a published
(and public) API, and a system API.

Whereas the system API is one that is subject to frequent refactorings,
and governs the internal shape of the system, the published API is that
which interfaces with third parties (be it as a producer or as a
consumer). As such, this should be a very stable API, and changes to it
should go through controlled @deprecation process spanning perhaps
several releases (to allow clients to catch up).

I am in favor of explicit documentation for published APIs, and am quite
comfortable with unit tests alone (or, God forbid! no documentation at
all) for system APIs (*).

Manuel Amago.
mailto:mamago@...

(*) If you find yourself having to dive into system APIs, you are
probably better off understanding the internals anyway, without needing
any documentation. Unit tests could come in handy if you make any
modifications, or to check that any changes you make don't disturb the
existing system.
